title-group.article-title: Synthesis and characterization of bisphenol-A ether diamine-based polyimide POSS nanocomposites for low K dielectric and flame-retardant applications

article-meta.aff: 1Polymer Nanocomposites Laboratory, Department of Chemical Engineering, Alagappa College of Technology, Anna University, Chennai, India
2Department of Chemistry, Arulmigu Palaniandavar College of Arts and Culture, Palani, India

author-notes.corresp: Mutukaruppan Alagar, Polymer Nanocomposites Laboratory, Department of Chemical Engineering, Alagappa College of Technology, Anna University, Chennai - 600 025, India Email: mkalagar@yahoo.com

abstract.p: Polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS) – polyimide (PI) hybrid nanocomposites were prepared by a two-step approach, bisphenol-A ether diamine (BAED) and pyromelletic dianhydride (PMDA) in 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) were used to prepare polyamic acid (PAA) to which varying weight percentages of OAPS in NMP were added. During the second step, the polycondensation was effected by thermal imidization. The formation of hybrid nanocomposites was confirmed by using FTIR spectra. The thermal properties of POSS-PI nanocomposites were studied using differential scanning calorimetry and thermogravimetric analysis. The lowest dielectric constant 2.68 was achieved for 15 wt.% POSS-PI material when compared with the value of 3.34 for the neat PI. Data from thermal studies indicate that the incorporation of POSS into polyimide significantly enhanced the glass transition temperature (T g), thermal stability, char yield and flame-retardant properties of hybrid nanocomposites than that of neat PI. The excellent combination of both dielectric and thermal properties of the material developed in the present study will find application in microelectronics.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hybrid organic–inorganic materials have become an expanding field of research as the introduction of inorganic molecules can improve the characteristics of a matrix. 1 Hybrid materials containing both inorganic and organic components are expected to enhance the performance behaviour relative to their non-hybrid materials. Due to the nano-length scales involved, nanocomposite materials attribute an extensive range of interfacial interactions that can result in significant changes relative to their component properties. 2

Among many engineering polymers, aromatic polyimides (PIs) are regarded as thermally stable polymers which possess an excellent mechanical strength and thermal stability. During the past decade, interest in these polymers has increased in response to increasing technological applications in a variety of fields such as aerospace, automobile engineering and microelectronics. Polyimides are usually prepared through a two-step reaction between aromatic diamines and aromatic tetracarboxylic dianhydrides in commercially available N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) to give polyamic acids (PAAs), and followed by thermal imidization. Recently, PIs possessing lower dielectric constants and higher dimensional stability than that of SiO2 have been extensively used in the microelectronics industry. 3
–8 Research studies in the field of high temperature aromatic PIs are focused on improving processability and solubility through the synthesis of new diamine or dianhydride monomers. Several approaches have already been made to introduce flexible bridging linkages (–NHCO–, –O–, and –SO2–) into the polymer backbone 9
–12 and for the incorporation of bulky substituents along the polymer backbone. 13
–17

Polyimides containing a large number of carbon double bonds can be expected to have a large polarization due to the increased mobility of p-electrons. The rigidity and thermal stability of the polyimide are due to the dense molecular packing. The high-energy bond and material density of polyimide leads to a larger electronic polarizability, and therefore a higher dielectric constant which is of significance in modern electronic devices. In order to obtain polymers with low dielectric constant, several research groups 18
–22 have explored the possibility of producing nanosized polymer matrices to exploit the advantages of low dielectric behaviour.

Polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS) is a kind of silsesquioxane with a cage structure and has attracted considerable research in recent years. POSS composites, including complete condensed POSS and incomplete condensed POSS, exhibit a major role in the modification of organic polymeric materials, because of their rigid inorganic core which provides molecular reinforcement, due to the organic groups present in the compound which increase the compatibility and processability of organic polymers, by improving the interaction between organic and inorganic phases. 23 The incorporation of POSS derivatives into organic polymeric materials exhibits significant improvement in polymer properties, such as resistance to oxidation and water absorption, high use temperature, surface hardening, mechanical, dielectric properties and reduction in flammability. A low dielectric constant material can also be made by incorporating cage-like polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS) into the polyimide matrix. 24
–31

In the present work, an attempt has been made to synthesize the polyimide using bisphenol-A ether diamine (BAED) with pyromelletic dianhydride (PMDA). Octa(aminophenyl)silsesquioxane (OAPS) of varying percentages has been incorporated into polyamic acid (PAA), to obtain POSS-PI hybrid nanocomposites by thermal imidization. The resulting nanocomposites are expected to possess enhanced thermal stability, char yield and the low dielectric constant required for high performance applications in aerospace and microelectronics.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Phenyltrichlorosilane, 10% Pd/C, was purchased from Aldrich, USA. Bisphenol-A, 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene, and anhydrous potassium carbonate were received from Loba Chemie. Benzyl trimethyl ammonium hydroxide (40% in methanol) solution, 98% formic acid, triethylamine, tetrahydrofuran, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), ethyl acetate and hexane were purchased from SD fine chemicals, India. NMP was purified by distillation under nitrogen atmosphere and dried over molecular sieves. Tetrahydrofuran (THF) was distilled under nitrogen atmosphere from Na/benzophenone immediately prior to use. Triethylamine was distilled over KOH. OAPS (Scheme 1) was synthesized and characterized as per the reported procedure.26–30

sec.title: Synthesis of 2,2-bis(4-(4-nitrophenoxy) phenyl)propane (I)
sec.p: Bisphenol-A (0.04 mol) was dissolved in 50 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) in a 100 mL flask, to which potassium carbonate (0.12 mol) was added and stirred for 30 min at 30 °C followed by the addition of 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene (0.08 mol). After this the mixture was heated at 100 °C for 12 h, cooled to 30 °C and poured into 200 mL of water to give a pale yellow solid. The yellow solid was washed thoroughly with water followed by methanol and hot water, and dried under vacuum at 100 °C to get 2,2-bis(4-(4-nitrophenoxy)phenyl)propane. The product was recrystallized from ethanol to get pure compound I (90%) (Scheme 2).

sec.title: Synthesis of 4-(4-(2-(4-(4-aminophenoxy)phenyl)propan-2-yl) phenoxy) benzenamine (BAED)
sec.p: To a suspension of purified 2,2-bis(4-(4-nitrophenoxy)phenyl)propane (0.04 mol) and 10% Pd/C (0.250 g) in ethanol (100 mL), at 50 °C hydrazine monohydrate (25 mL) was added slowly. The mixture was then heated to 80–90 °C and maintained at the same temperature for another 3 h. The reaction mixture was filtered in hot condition to remove Pd/C, cooled to room temperature to get white crystals of BAED (85%) (Scheme 2).
MASS M/Z [M+H] +: 411.3.

sec.title: Preparation of PI and POSS-PI nanocomposites
sec.p: The polyimide was prepared via condensation of BAED with PMDA using NMP as a solvent. Known quantities of BAED and PMAD (1 : 1 mol/mol) were dissolved separately in 20 mL of NMP. The resulting solutions were mixed in a three-necked flask that had been purged with nitrogen gas to remove moisture. The mixture was stirred under nitrogen at 30 °C for 6 h, to yield polyamic acid (PAA). The PAA obtained was then cast on a smooth glass substrate and thermally treated at 80 °C for 8 h, 200 °C for 2 h and 300 °C for 2 h. 29

For the synthesis of OAPS incorporated polyimide (POSS-PI) nanocomposites, OAPS/NMP was added to a freshly prepared PAA solution and stirred for 2 h under N2 at 30 °C. After 2 h, the OAPS/PAA solution was cast on a smooth glass substrate and thermally treated at 80 °C for 8 h, 200 °C for 2 h and 300 °C for 2 h. The thin and dark brown colored films formed were stripped from the glass substrates with the help of deionized water and dried at 100 °C in a vacuum oven and then taken for further characterization.

sec.title: Physico-chemical studies
sec.p: Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded on a Perkin Elmer 6X FTIR spectrometer. About 100 mg of optical-grade KBr was ground with a sufficient quantity of the solid sample to make 1 wt.% mixture for making KBr pellets.

All 1 H-NMR analyses were done in DMSO-d 6 and recorded on a Bruker 500 spectrometer. The molecular weight of BAED was determined by using the electron spray ionization method with an Agilent 6330 Ion Trap mass spectrometer.

sec.title: Thermal studies
sec.p: The calorimetric analysis was performed on a Netzsch DSC-200 differential scanning calorimeter. The instrument was calibrated with indium supplied by Netzsch. Measurements were performed under a continuous flow of nitrogen (60 mL min−1). All the samples (about 10 mg in weight) were heated from ambient to 400 °C and the thermograms were recorded at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1.

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Netzsch STA 409 thermogravimetric analyzer. The instrument was calibrated with calcium oxalate and aluminium supplied by Netzsch. The samples (about 50 mg) were heated from ambient temperature to 900 °C under a continuous flow of nitrogen (60 mL min−1), at 10 °C min−1.

sec.title: Dielectric studies
sec.p: The dielectric constant of the neat polyimide and the POSS-modified polyimide systems were determined with the help of an impedance analyser (Solartron impedance/gain phase analyser 1260) at room temperature using a platinum (Pt) electrode at 30 °C at a frequency range of 1 MHz. This experiment was repeated four times under the same conditions.

sec.title: Morphological studies
sec.p: A JEOL JSM-6360 field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) was used to record the SEM pictures and the samples were prepared by coating gold on their surface for SEM measurements.

A JEOL JEM-3010 analytical transmission electron microscope operating at 300 kV with a measured point-to-point resolution of 0.23 nm was used and the TEM samples were prepared by dissolving the polymers in DMF and then mounted on carbon-coated Cu TEM grids and dried for 24 h at room temperature to form a film of < 100 nm size.

sec.title: Monomer synthesis
sec.p: The bisphenol-A ether diamine (BAED) (Scheme 2) was prepared in two steps. First, the compound I (bisphenol-A either linked dinitro) was prepared by o-arylation with bisphenol-A and 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene in the presence of anhydrous potassium carbonate in DMF. In the second step, catalytic reduction of compound I with hydrazine hydrate and Pd/C in the presence of ethanol was performed to yield BAED (II)

The structure of compounds I and II were confirmed by FTIR and NMR spectroscopic analysis. Compound I gave two characteristic bands at 1529 and 1348 cm−1 which indicated the symmetric and asymmetric stretching for the nitro group respectively, and the absence of OH bands at 3530 and 3401 cm−1 was also observed. After reduction, the characteristic absorptions of the nitro group disappeared, and the characteristic bands of amino group N–H stretching at 3410 and 3352 cm−1 (Figure 1) appeared. The 1 H-NMR (Figure 2) also confirmed the BAED diamine (II) structure and the MASS spectrum analysis (Figure 3) confirmed the presence of BAED diamine (II). M/Z [M+H]+: 411.3.

caption.p: IR spectrum of bisphenol-A ether diamine (BAED).
MASS spectrum of bisphenol-A ether diamine (BAED).

sec.title: Structure of POSS-PI hybrid nanocomposites
sec.p: The PI and the POSS-PI nanocomposites (Scheme 3) were prepared by the reaction of BAED, OAPS and PMDA via a two-step method. Figure 4 shows the FTIR spectra of varying combinations of POSS-PI nanocomposites. The intensities of the absorption bands at 1777 cm−1 (unsymmetric –C–O in the imide groups), 1726 cm−1 (symmetric –C–O in the imide groups) and 1375 cm–1 (–C–N in the imide groups) were increased with the increase in imidization temperature. After heating at 80 °C for 8 h, 200 °C for 2 h and 300 °C for 2 h the amide groups converted to imide groups which was confirmed the absence of peaks at 1550 cm−1 (–C–N) cm−1 and 1660 cm−1 (–C–O), respectively. The absorption band of POSS at 1090 cm−1 (asymmetric Si–O–Si) was observed in the spectra of all POSS–PI nanocomposites.

sec.title: Differential scanning calorimetry
sec.p: The glass transition temperature (T g) values of the neat PI and POSS-PI were obtained from DSC. The DSC data are presented in Table 1. In the present study the POSS–PI nanocomposites exhibited a considerably higher T g value than that of the neat PI. The T g increased from 286 °C for the neat PI to 325 °C for POSS-PI nanocomposites. The T g values for 0, 5, 10 and 15 wt.% POSS-incorporated PI were 286, 298, 312 and 325 °C, respectively. The T g values increased with the increases in percentage concentration of OAPS. The increase of glass transition temperature with incorporation of POSS could have occurred for two reasons. First, the incorporation of POSS increases the crosslinking density of the resulting nanocomposites. Second, POSS is a rigid body and so an increase of POSS concentration would increase the rigidity of the nanocomposite system. The increase in cross-linking density leads to an increase in the T g value of the resulting composite. 32 Although, the incorporation of POSS increases the free volume in the POSS-PI nanocomposites, this effect can be compensated by the increase in the cross-linking density. 33

caption.p: Thermal properties, LOI and dielectric constant of POSS-PI nanocomposites.

sec.title: Thermogravimetric analysis
sec.p: Figure 5 and Table 1 show the thermal stability data of neat PI and POSS-PI nanocomposites. The incorporation of OAPS into polyimide improved the thermal stability and enhanced the degradation temperature with increasing percentage concentration of OAPS. The thermogram shows that the initial degradation temperatures for the POSS- PI nanocomposites were lower than those of neat polyimide. This may be due to the low molecular weight of the PI-POSS which was caused by the unequal amounts of diamine and dianhydride added in these systems. 34 The residual char yields after the incorporation of 0, 5, 10 and 15 wt.% POSS cube into the PI were 43.4, 47.6, 48.8 and 50.4% respectively, at 900 °C and this indicated that these hybrid materials were thermally stable. The cubic silica cores and phenyl groups with good thermal stability and the stable covalent bonds between the two components limited the continuous decomposition of the PI phase. 29 The enhanced thermal stability may be explained by the presence of the partial ionic nature and the high bond energy of Si–O–Si, which may cause the delay in degradation.

sec.title: Limiting oxygen index
sec.p:
The limiting oxygen index (LOI) represents the lowest environmental oxygen content for sustaining a flame. It is used to quantify the flame retardancy of organic polymers. The oxygen volume content of the ambient atmosphere is about 21%. Therefore, a material exhibiting an LOI above 21% might show flame-retardant properties. Generally, materials with LOI values higher than 26 would show self-extinguishing behavior and can be considered to be highly flame retardant. This oxidized layer serves as a barrier against heat and oxygen diffusion, which leads to the flame retardation of polymers in the high-temperature region and also gives high char yields. It has also been reported that a high char yield leads to high flame retardancy. 35,36
LOI=0.40( σ )+17.5(
Van Krevelen′s equation
)

where σ is the char yield at 900 °C. In the present study the flame retardancy behaviour of polyimide and the various weight percentages of incorporated POSS-PI were analyzed with the char yield at 900 °C using Van Krevelen’s equation. 37 The values are listed in Table 1 they were found to be in the range of 34.9–37.7. Furthermore, the flame retardancy increased as the concentration of POSS increased. Burning behavior was correlated with the crosslink density of the polymer; i.e. with increasing crosslink density, the flammability resistance increased due to formation of higher char. Thus, the developed POSS-PI nanomaterials can be considered to be good flame-retardant materials.

sec.title: Dielectric constant
sec.p: A lower dielectric constant is one of the most desirable properties for the next generation of electronic devices. Table 1 gives the values of dielectric constant of the different POSS-PI nanocomposites with varying percentages of POSS concentration. The dielectric constant of the hybrid decreased as the amount of POSS increased. The measured dielectric constant of the neat PI was 3.34, whereas the lowest dielectric constant of the 15 wt.% POSS-PI was 2.68. The reduction in the dielectric constant of the POSS-PI hybrids may be explained in terms of creation of pores and a free volume increase by the presence of the rigid and large POSS structure resulting in the PI network. 30 The signal propagation delay time of integrated circuits is proportional to the square root of the dielectric constant of the matrix, and the signal propagation loss is proportional to the square root of the dielectric constant and dissipation factor of the matrix. Thus, a material with low dielectric constant and low dissipation factor will reduce the signal propagation delay time and the signal propagation loss 38 and improve the effective and efficient functioning of electronic instruments.

sec.title: Morphology
sec.p: Figure 6 show the SEM micrograph of the fractured surface of neat PI, 5 and 15 wt.% POSS-incorporated PI nanocomposites. All POSS-PI nanocomposites displayed a homogeneous and smooth morphology as can be observed from the SEM micrographs. Figure 6(a) shows that the neat PI has a smooth and homogeneous surface and a similar smooth homogeneous morphology was also observed for different POSS-incorporated POSS-PI nanocomposites. Figure 6(b) and (c) are SEM micrographs of 5 and 15 wt.% POSS-incorporated POSS-PI hybrids; they exhibit no distinguishable phase separation and dark regions which indicates perfect bonding between PI and POSS with molecular level dispersion of OAPS throughout the hybrid. This was further confirmed by TEM analysis. Figure 7(a), (b) and (c) represent the TEM micrographs of 5, 10 and 15 wt.% OAPS-incorporated POSS-PI nanocomposites, it shows the homogenous morphology. No localized domains and no phase segregation were observed even at nanometer scale, implying that POSS cages were well dispersed in the polymeric system and no POSS aggregation occurred.

caption.p: SEM micrograph of POSS-PI nanocomposites: (a) neat PI; (b) 5 wt.% POSS-PI; (c) 15 wt.% POSS-PI.
TEM micrograph of POSS-PI nanocomposites: (a) 5 wt.% POSS-PI; (b) 10 wt.% POSS-PI; (c) 15 wt.% POSS-PI.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: POSS-PI hybrid nanocomposites were prepared successfully via condensation polymerization of BAED and PMDA in the presence of OAPS. The resulting POSS-PI nanocomposites exhibited excellent thermal properties, such as high glass transition temperature, thermal stability and flame retardancy. The T g values increased from 286 to 325 °C, due to the three-dimensional nature of POSS which restricted the mobility of the polymeric chain. A lower dielectric constant 2.68 was obtained for 15 wt.% POSS-PI in comparison with that of neat PI (3.34). The newly developed POSS-PI nanocomposites with high thermal stability and low dielectric constant are expected to find high performance applications in the fields of aerospace and microelectronics.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors thank DST (Nanomission),SR/NM/NS-18/2010, New Delhi, Government of India, for the financial support and the Department of Mechanical Engineering, Anna University, for providing the scanning electron microscopy analysis facility. The authors also acknowledge M. Vinoba, A. Chandramohan, C. Truppati Raja, K.V.Thiruvengadaravi and Miss M. Mandhakini, research scholars, Polymer Composite Lab, Department of Chemical Engineering, Anna University.
